t_process_library::tip_collection::tips[: Lights approximately 3 feet away from your character are the most flattering.
Good photographs are about peak action and drama. Choose your moments with that in mind.
Don't forget to get signature shots when possible.
Even if you will only use one image in your story, shoot a variety of images to choose from.
"The size of an object in the frame should equal it's importance at that moment." -Alfred Hitchcock
For a series your images should be composed as identically as possible.
Find different sounds and quotes that help tell your story.
Focus on a single primary topic to tell a concise and clear story.
Be clear about your topic or goal when requesting an interview.
Be calm. Relaxing will help your interview subject relax too.
Record first hand observations and interviews whenever possible.
Ensure the most important part of your shot fills at least 50% of the frame.
Get a variety of images -- close-ups, medium shots and wide shots.
Make sure your subject is in focus and not distorted by something in the frame.
Always know what you want from the interview.
Decide the best place to record from and hold your frame in place until complete.
If it is windy, point your camera away from the wind, or block if with your body or a wall.
Prioritize your questions and identify the single, most essential bit of information you need.
Tell us how the issue is changing in response to the actions of characters in the story.
Tell us how the event changes as it progresses.
Low light can produce poor shots. Shooting outside or in a sunny room can give you great light.
When preparing to record, hold your device in a way that is comfortable and natural.
Combine clips of different sizes or types to create a complementary sequence.
A climax is the answer on the question that holds the attention of the viewer. Don't give it away too early.
A climax is the answer on the question that keeps your listener listening. Don't give it away too early.
Get as close to your subject as possible.
Ask yourself for every clip: does it tell me something new?
Don't take just one photograph. Take lots. Experiment.
Tell us what is expected for the event the next time it happens.
Remember, without good sound your images only tell half the story.
When shooting in dangerous situations always have an exit strategy.
A good series should be made up of five strong images. If you have more good shots, add them in though.
Tell us some interesting facts about the history of the issue or why it started.
Don't ask 'closed' questions that can be answered in one word such as 'yes' or 'no'.
Keep the conversation moving. Ask: Why? What happened next? What do you mean?
Simply changing the angle of view can make a much better photograph.
Check your audio level using headphones before you start recording.
Tell us some interesting facts about the history of the event or why it happens.
Save sensitive questions for the end.
If the light source is directly behind your subject, the subject will be dark and difficult to see.
Use multiple sources of audio to tell your story.
Your story will be more interesting if you interview characters with opposing viewpoints.
Do some research before the interview when possible. You will ask better, more relevant questions.
Ask yourself for every clip: does it tell me something new about my major question?
Record your subject with the light source directly on the subject.
Taking your picture from an interesting angle of view can make a much better portrait.
Sound is half of the information in a video, consider it for every shot.
To shoot a sequence you need to break down the elements of your story into individual shots.
Think Rule-of-Thirds.
Don't hold your breath, set your shot, and breathe. When your shot is steady, begin recording
Every new image should contain new information that advances your story.
If your questions do not provide a satisfactory answer, change your approach.
Pay attention to the edges of your frame not just the middle.
End the interview by asking, "Is there anything else you would like to add?"
Hit record before you ask a question to record a few seconds of silence before speaking.
Ask hard questions, but remember to be polite. A polite request will go a long way.
Use follow-up questions if you need more information.
In a crowd, shoot away from the crowd for better audio, ask your subject to face you.
In your interview, remember to be tough but fair.
Shoot different size shots to create an effective sequence.
Clear and interesting sound can paint a good picture in the mind of anyone who listens.
Even if time is limited, make a plan, do not shoot everything you see.
Every story has a major question. What's the question you've answered at the end of your item?
Even if time is limited, make a plan, do not record everything you hear.
When recording an interview, prepare at least 15 questions.
Think about the audience you want to reach when considering what Topic and Format to use.
Well composed shots have space in the direction the subject is facing, or moving.
Hold your device close to the subject, and just below their mouth.
If you can feel the light source on the back of your neck on a sunny day, you will have the best lighting in that situation.
Remember: the viewer won't know anything about your story that you don't show them in the photograph.
"If your picture's not good enough, you're not close enough." -Robert Capa
Keep recording for at least 15 seconds, if the clip is too long, trim it.
Have a one-sentence explanation of your story for your characters.
Ask only one question at a time.
Get to the most important question quickly in the interview.
Tell us what is expected for the issue in the future.
Don't pan. If you want a new angle, stop recording. Change your frame, and record a new shot.
Always update your White Balance setting when you move to a different lighting situation.
Does your image illustrate context?
Do not place your subject in the center of the frame, use the rule of thirds.
Start the camera rolling before the action begins and don't stop recording until after it ends.
Good photography is all about light. Are you using available light as best you can?
t_process_library::title: Process Story
t_process_library::tip_collection::tips[: Use your own voice as little as possible, tell the story through the voices of others.
Aim for 8 to 20 images in your final edit. Shoot more pictures than you plan to use.
Do not stop recording until the action in your shot is complete.
Courtesy can help establish trust and improve your interviews.
If it is windy, point your camera away from the wind, or protect your mic.
Listen for background noise that may harm the quality of your story before you click record.
Machines make a lot of noise, turn them off if possible, or change your location if you can.
Crowds and busy streets make a lot of noise. Do not shoot interviews in front of crowds or busy streets.
Know yourself, be aware of your biases don't let them influence how you portray your story.
